At 02:39 26/01/2006, Derek wrote:
>On 1/25/06, Colin Green 
><<mailto:cgreen@...>cgreen@...> wrote:
>
>Ok but consider these points:
>
>1) If you clone a genome and the offspring replaces an existing genome
>that had less structure, then you have increased overall complexity
>within the population.
>
>
>To replace an existing genome, an offspring should have a higher 
>fitness than the one it replaced.  In this case, the additional 
>complexity should be helping increase fitness, so it shouldn't be 
>considered bloat.

I also allow a new genome to replace an old one if they are of equal 
fitness (my current fitness scheme is quantized, so I get a lot of 
equal fitnesses).  I do this because it means that the population is 
changing (e.g. searching) even when it is not making progress.

Anybody have any thoughts on that vis-a-vis bloat?

>2) Now if we consider that some additive mutations are neutral then we
>can assume that these will get cloned and propagated through a
>population over time.
>3) Overall, mutation is more likely to find neutral additions than
>neutral deletions - assuming equal amount of both types.
>
>
>What are your justifications for #3?

I think he's thinking of the case where, if you have a genome where 
most parts are functional, then the chances are that a deletion will 
be deleterious.  In the same case, however, there is a good chance of 
an addition being neutral, because there is a good chance of an 
addition being functionless.   However, if we imagine that population 
persisting for some time, then it will acquire more and more 
non-functional structure (for the reasons just outlined) and to my 
mind it ought to eventually arrive at an equilibrium point where the 
chances for adding or deleting structure are roughly 
equal.  Personally I have never seen that, however....

Now!  Here's an analysis that might explain the situation, and 
sure-enough, I think the explanation comes down to crossover.

--

Suppose that we think about some subset of a population.  Without 
crossover we can imagine that this subset will come to an equilibrium 
point where there is enough non-functional structure that deletion 
has increased to match additions.

To reach this point, the subset will have acquired some set, A of 
non-functional genes (a1, a2, a3...).

OK, now suppose that another subset of the population is also at 
equilibrium, it will also have a set of non-functional genes B (b1, b2, b3...).

Now, what are the chances that the sets A and B contain the same 
genes?  Essentially zero!

So, as soon as there is a crossover between A and B, if the new 
individual is keeping a significant number of the unmatched genes, it 
will immediately have a greater than equilibrium proportion of 
non-functional genes.

--

Obviously in reality there is no neat subdivision of the population 
into completely disjunct subpopulations, but I think I have 
illustrated an extreme case and that the more general interpretation would be:

1) as long as two breeding individuals each have some gene unmatched 
in the other, then the offspring will be bigger than either parent.
2) the more different the two parents are, then the more we might 
expect the offspring to grow by.

--

I'm thinking this brings me back around to my idea of not taking all 
unmatched genes regardless.  Do we think that with a 50% change of 
keeping each unmatched gene, that will balance things.  e.g. if we 
assume that each individual is contributing roughly the same number 
of them, then simple arithmetic should suggest we have twice as many 
as we need, so halving them...

         Ian

In 15 minutes everybody will be in the future.
